adverbs.description: overtop (comparative more overtop, superlative most overtop)

entries.meaning: (now chiefly Canada, US) Over the top. [from 18th c.]
examples: Paul put the skull back in its proper place, put back the coffin lid, and kicked dirt and rocks overtop.

verbs.description: overtop (third-person singular simple present overtops, present participle overtopping, simple past and past participle overtopped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be higher than; to rise over the top of. [from 16th c.]
examples: There was a single birch tree that overtopped the other trees on the island, and was now picked out against the moon-drenched sky.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place too many toppings on.
